body.p:
To his Excellency-
Gov Thos E Bramlette.
Frankfort Kentucky

The undersigned petitioner respectfully sheweth that at the December term 1863. of the Kenton Circuit Court he was fined $50, on three several Indictments numbered respectively 782-783 & 785, for selling liquor to minors. The 1st he repleived Dec 30/63 the 2d he replieved the same day. and the 3d he replieved Jany 12/64. He has always been an honorable man and tried to keep biding house_ but these were th young men, working in a near his Coffee House who leaked, eased to be over twenty one years of age_ they were doing business for themselves- made their own contracts- and were to all intents and purposes acting for themselves. One of them lacked but a few months of being 21. All were grown-and to a person-not related to them- they had all the actions and appearance of adult men- and upon their testimony he was convicted-upon the instigation of one John Beasly, who became offended, because affiant attempted to collect from him a small liquor bill. Affiant
keeps a regularly licensed Coffee House in the City of Covington

Personally appeared before me John F. Fisk a Notary Public in and for the Courts of Kenton and state of Kentucky Henry Crout_ subscribed and made oath to the truth of all the statements in the above petition Given under my hand and seal of Office this Aug 19th 1864

John F. Fisk
N.P. K. C. Ky

The undersigned jurors who tried the Indictments Nos 782, ^783, & 785,^ state that the facts and appearences, of the witnesses and their testimony is truthfully set out in the proceding petition. The Petetitioners a good citizen -an honorable man-We think this a fair case for Executive clemency and pray that it may be exercised in this case

Jurors Names
Joel Dedman
G. W. Lowry
J. Sanderson
Thomas Robson
W N Rogers
James Spilman
